text: Hey guys, one general question, does Betfair act as a Market Maker providing liquidity in the markets?

elements.text: Hey guys, one general question, does Betfair act as a Market Maker providing liquidity in the markets?

text: I'm looking into markets with very small amount of money matched but there are always odds there (high spread of course). I'm wondering who provides these initial odds

elements.text: I'm looking into markets with very small amount of money matched but there are always odds there (high spread of course). I'm wondering who provides these initial odds

text: Nothing about that scenario requires Betfair to be the market maker

be acting as a market maker in a sense via cross matching (I think)

text: I've seen a fair bit of stuff on twitter regarding Betfair profiting from cross matching. Is this in any way true? Is there some way in which XM allows them to scrape pennies from the granulatiry of the price ladder?

elements.text: I've seen a fair bit of stuff on twitter regarding Betfair profiting from cross matching. Is this in any way true? Is there some way in which XM allows them to scrape pennies from the granulatiry of the price ladder?

text: granularity*

elements.text: granularity*

text: Yes, that's right

elements.text: Yes, that's right

text: Betfair can act as market maker in markets that might have low liquidity, particularly in-play

elements.text: Betfair can act as market maker in markets that might have low liquidity, particularly in-play

text: In this respect, Betfair is only really "seeding" the market and making it available for others to use. Without seeding a lot of these markets would be "dead"

elements.text: In this respect, Betfair is only really "seeding" the market and making it available for others to use. Without seeding a lot of these markets would be "dead"

text: So <@UBS7QANF3> in a hypothetical situation, say a tennis match with nothing on the board. I put in a speculative back at 75 for £2 on player A. My understanding is that XM will put up £150 available to back at 1.01 on Player B (please correct me if that is wrong). If someone is daft enough to take that back on at 1.01 do betfair just pocket the 50p of my £2 quid I just lost (assuming player B wins). Is it that simple or is there more subtlety to it than that? Is it simply betfair rounding down due to the quantized nature of the price ladder?

elements.text: So

in a hypothetical situation, say a tennis match with nothing on the board. I put in a speculative back at 75 for £2 on player A. My understanding is that XM will put up £150 available to back at 1.01 on Player B (please correct me if that is wrong). If someone is daft enough to take that back on at 1.01 do betfair just pocket the 50p of my £2 quid I just lost (assuming player B wins). Is it that simple or is there more subtlety to it than that? Is it simply betfair rounding down due to the quantized nature of the price ladder?

text: Yes it's just due to the granularity of the price ladder

elements.text: Yes it's just due to the granularity of the price ladder

text: There aren't tennis matches with nothing there :wink:

elements.text: There aren't tennis matches with nothing there
